REVERSED AND REMANDED


  
    
      
        Attorney General Henry
        Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh,
        Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Assistant Attorney
        General W. Rutledge Martin, Office of the Attorney General, all of
        Columbia: and Solicitor Ralph E. Hoisington, of Charleston, for
        Appellant.
        Assistant Appellate Defender
        Eleanor Duffy Cleary, Office of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:  Jonathan
Frazier pleaded guilty to armed robbery and was sentenced to a sentence not to
exceed six years under the Youthful Offenders Act, South Carolina Code section
24-19-10 to 160 (Supp. 2004).  The State appeals, arguing that the trial
judge erred by denying its motion to reconsider the sentence because Frazier did
not qualify as a youthful offender.  We reverse.[1]   
FACTS
During the morning of November 5,
2001, Frazier and two others planned and carried out a robbery at the Fairfield
Inn in North Charleston.  While Frazier and Antonio
Staley waited in the truck, Lawanda Collins went inside the hotel and propped
the dinning room door open for Frazier.  Frazier entered the hotel through
the opened door, wearing a nylon mask and carrying an unloaded rifle.  He
then took the hotel clerk to the bathroom and secured it by tying the door shut
with an extension cord.  Frazier helped Staley carry the hotel safe out to
the truck and Collins helped them put it in the truck.  Staley went back
into the hotel to wipe off their fingerprints.  After leaving the hotel,
all three went home and unloaded the safe.  Later that day they tried to
open the safe with a sledgehammer, but it broke, so they had to buy a torch and
get three other people to help them with it.  When they almost had the safe
open, Staley wanted to take it somewhere else so the others would not have
access to it.  After driving the safe to Sheep Island,
the three opened the safe and split the cash equally.  The three then
burned all the checks and gift certificates from the safe and hid the safe in Mt. Pleasant by the water.
Frazier gave a written statement to
the police on December 7, 2001 and was willing to testify against Staley. 
On June 26, 2003, Frazier pleaded guilty to armed robbery.  The trial judge
sentenced Frazier to a sentence not to exceed six years under the Youthful
Offenders Act, South Carolina Code section 24-19-10 to 160 (Supp. 2004). 
The judge did not order credit for the 557 days Frazier had served awaiting
trial.  The State filed a motion to reconsider the sentence on June 27,
2003.  The judge heard and denied the motion on November 20, 2003. 
The State now
appeals.                      
LAW/ANALYSIS
The State
argues that the trial judge erred by denying its motion to reconsider the
sentence because Frazier did not qualify as a youthful offender.  We agree.
South Carolina Code section
24-19-10(d)(ii) (Supp. 2004) defines a â€œyouthful offenderâ€ as an offender
who is â€œseventeen but less than twenty-five years of age at the time of
conviction for an offense that is not a violent crime . . . and that is a
misdemeanor, a Class D, Class E, or Class F felony, or a felony which provides
for a maximum term of imprisonment of fifteen years or less.â€  Frazier
was twenty-four years old at the time of his guilty plea and he pled guilty to
armed robbery. 
The South Carolina Code designates
armed robbery as a â€œviolent crimeâ€ and establishes that it is a class â€œAâ€
felony.  S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 16-1-60 and 90(A) (Supp. 2004).  The Code
also provides that, as a felony, armed robbery carries a â€œmandatory minimum
term of not less than ten years or more than thirty years, no part of which may
be suspended or probation granted.â€  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-11-330(A)
(2003).  Therefore, the State correctly argues that Frazier does not
qualify as a youthful offender under the Act. 
â€œA trial judge generally has wide
discretion in determining what sentence to impose.â€  State v. Franklin,
267 S.C. 240, 246, 226 S.E.2d 896, 898 (1976).  â€œ[T]his court has no
jurisdiction to review a sentence, provided it is within the limits provided by
statute for the discretion of the trial court, and is not the result of
prejudice, oppression or corrupt motive.â€  Id.; State v. Benning, 338 S.C. 59,
64, 524 S.E.2d 852, 856 (Ct. App. 1999). 
â€œ[T]he effect of the enactment of
[the Youthful Offenders Act] statute was to provide alternative methods of
sentencing youthful offenders, leaving the decision as to its application in
each case to the discretion of the trial judge.â€  Powell v. State,
262 S.C. 592, 595, 206 S.E.2d 883, 884 (1974).  However, â€œ[t]he exercise
of a sound judicial discretion must and should be performed in every case with a
conscientious regard for what is just and proper under the circumstances.â€ 
State v. Scates, 212 S.C. 150, 155-56, 46 S.E.2d 693,
695 (1948).  Here, because Frazier does not qualify as a youthful offender
under the Act, the trial judge erred by denying the Stateâ€™s motion to
reconsider Frazierâ€™s sentence.
REVERSED AND REMANDED. 
GOOLSBY, BEATTY, and SHORT, J.J.,
concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215,
SCACR.

PER CURIAM: George Ducworth,
solicitor for the Tenth Judicial Circuit, brought this civil forfeiture action
against Donald Stubblefield seeking the forfeiture of Stubblefieldâ€™s real
property pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§44-53-520 (2002).  The trial judge
heard the case without a jury and confirmed the forfeiture in favor of the
State.  Stubblefield appeals.  We affirm[1] pursuant to Rule 220(b)(2), SCACR and the
following authorities:
1.  The trial judge did not err
in affirming the forfeiture because the state had probable cause to seize
Stubblefieldâ€™s property:  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-53-520(a)(4) (2002)
(providing that â€œ[a]ll property, both real and personal, which in any manner
is knowingly used to facilitate production, manufacturing, distribution, sale,
importation, exportation, or trafficking in various controlled substancesâ€ is
subject to forfeiture); Medlock v. One 1985 Jeep Cherokee VIN
1JCWB782FT129001, 322 S.C. 127, 131, 470 S.E.2d 373, 376 (1996) (â€œThe
purpose of a forfeiture hearing is to confirm that the State had probable cause
to seize the property forfeited.â€); Boas v. Smith, 786 F.2d 605,
609 (4th Cir.1986) (stating the initial burden is on the State to demonstrate
â€œprobable cause for belief that a substantial connection exists between the
property to be forfeited and the criminal activity defined by statuteâ€); Medlock,
322 S.C. at 131, 470 S.E.2d at 376 (quoting S.C.Code Ann. Â§
44-53-586(b)(1) (Supp. 1994)) (â€œIf probable cause is shown, the burden then
shifts to the [property] owner to prove that he or she â€˜was not a consenting
party to, or privy to, or did not have knowledge of, the use of the property
which made it subject to seizure and forfeiture.â€™â€) City of Sumter
Police Depâ€™t v. One (1) Blue Mazda Truck VIN No. JM2UF1132N0294812,
330 S.C. 371, 373, 498 S.E.2d 894, 895 (Ct. App. 1998) (holding an action for
forfeiture of property is a civil action at law); Townes Assocs. v. City of
Greenville, 266 S.C. 81, 86, 221 S.E.2d 773, 775 (1976) (â€œIn an
action at law, on appeal of a case tried without a jury, the findings of fact of
the judge will not be disturbed upon appeal unless found to be without evidence
which reasonably supports the judge's findings.â€).
2.  The forfeiture of
Stubblefieldâ€™s property does not violate the Excessive Fines Clause: Austin
v. United States, 509 U.S. 602, 113 S.Ct. 2801, 125 L.Ed.2d 488
(1993) (holding the Excessive Fines Clause is applicable to civil forfeiture
cases); United States v. Candler, 36 F.3d 358, 365 (4th Cir.1994)
(stating to determine if a violation of the Excessive Fines Clause occurred, a
court must examine (1) the nexus between the offense and the property and the
extent of the propertyâ€™s role in the offense, (2) the role and culpability of
the owner, and (3) the possibility of separating offending property that can
readily be separated from the remainder); Id. (providing the following
factors to consider in measuring the strength and extent of the nexus between
the property and the offense: (1) whether the use of the property in the offense
was deliberate and planned or merely incidental and fortuitous; (2) whether the
property was important to the success of the illegal activity; (3) the time
during which the property was illegally used and the spacial extent of its use;
(4) whether its illegal use was an isolated event or had been repeated; and (5)
whether the purpose of acquiring, maintaining or using the property was to carry
out the offense); Medlock at 132, 470 S.E.2d at 377 (adopting the Fourth
Circuit Court of Appealsâ€™ three-part instrumentality test to determine when a
violation occurs). 
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., and STILWELL and
KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.     

[1]  Because oral argument would not aid the court in resolving
the issues on appeal, we decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule

title: State v. Lussardi
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
Hugh Lussardi, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Spartanburg County
Â J. Derham Cole, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-529
Submitted September 1, 2005 â€“ Filed September 16, 2005Â Â 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Robert M. Dudek, Office of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry D. McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, AssistantÂ  Attorney General Deborah R. J. Shupe, Office of the Attorney General, of Columbia, and Solicitor Harold W. Gowdy, III, of Spartanburg, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  A jury found Hugh Lussardi guilty of first degree burglary and grand larceny.Â  He was sentenced to life in prison for first degree burglary and five years for grand larceny.Â  Lussardi appeals, arguing the indictment was insufficient, the trial court erred by allowing the State to introduce Lussardiâ€™s two prior burglary convictions because they were more prejudicial than probative, and the trial court erred by sentencing Lussardi to life imprisonment without parole because his two prior burglaries were committed in a continuous course of conduct.Â  We affirm.[1] 
 
 FACTS
    On January 28, 2002, Jody Mabry returned home from work and discovered that the doors to his garage[2] were open.Â  Upon inspection, Mabry noticed that the walk-in door had been smashed and his four-wheeler was missing.Â  Mabry also noticed fresh four-wheeler tracks leading out of the building, around the building, through the woods behind the building, and then turning right onto Mount Olive Road.Â  After discovering that his four-wheeler was gone, Mabry walked to his grandmotherâ€™s house to inquire if she had seen anyone around his house during the day.Â  Mabry then returned home and called the police.Â  Officer Randall Bogan dusted for fingerprints on the garage and on a bar that was used to pry the door open, but he was unable to get any prints.
    Sheila Culbreth, who is Mabryâ€™s Aunt and lives across the street from Mabry, testified she heard her dogs barking that afternoon, so she went to her door to see what was outside.Â  When she looked outside, she saw two men walking up the road.Â  She testified that one of the men had long blonde hair and was wearing a type of cap on his head.Â  She said the other man had dark hair.Â  Culbreth said she did not get a good look at their faces because they never looked at her.Â  Shortly after Culbreth saw the two men in the street, she heard a banging noise and something running in the distance, but she did not see anything.Â  Culbreth saw the dark-haired man, who she later identified as Lussardi, again about two or three days later when she found him standing in her driveway when she came home from work.Â  She saw his face and noticed that he had a beard. 
    Thomas Lawter testified that Lussardi was at his house on January 28 and Lussardi wanted him to help him â€œgo get a four-wheeler.â€Â  The two men had been drinking at Lawterâ€™s house.Â  Lawter said Lussardi used a steel rod to break into Mabryâ€™s garage and then drove Mabryâ€™s four-wheeler out of the garage.Â  Lawter said he was scared and hid in the woods while Lussardi broke into the building, but he got on the back of the four-wheeler after Lussardi had stolen it.Â  The two of them then rode the four-wheeler through the woods to Lawterâ€™s house on Corn Mill Road and parked the vehicle behind Lawterâ€™s house.Â  The next morning, Lussardi sold the four-wheeler to a third party.Â  Lawter gave a statement to the sheriffâ€™s department on February 7, 2002, after the police had come to his house looking for Lussardi.Â  Lawter agreed to plead guilty to the charge.Â  Lawter said that he had long gray hair and was wearing a bandana at the time of the incident.Â Â Â Â  
    Lussardi was found guilty of first degree burglary and grand larceny.Â  He was sentenced to life in prison for first degree burglary and five years for grand larceny.Â  Lussardi made a motion for a new trial, which was denied.Â  Lussardi now appeals.Â 
 
    
 
    LAW/ANALYSIS 
          I.Â  IndictmentÂ Â Â Â Â  
        
            Lussardi argues the trial court erred by allowing the case to go forward as a first degree burglary case and by denying his motion for new trial because the indictment was insufficient.Â  We disagree.
            On appeal, Lussardi claims the indictment failed to give him notice of what he was called upon to defend and failed to protect him against double jeopardy because it stated that Lussardi entered Mabryâ€™s â€œdwelling.â€Â  Lussardi did not directly raise this issue to the trial judge as a defect in the indictment, but indirectly raised it in his request to suppress Lussardiâ€™s prior record on the basis that the statute violates the United States and South Carolina Constitutions.Â  Lussardi argued that Mabryâ€™s garage â€œwas a building, not a dwelling; and therefore to allow the introduction into evidence of his prior record merely for the purposes of establishing a burglary first brings into question his ability to defend himself because he has a right not to be incriminated.â€[3]Â  In response, the trial judge ruled that â€œbased upon that case law and those prior determinations by our courts, I find that the defendantâ€™s motion to preclude and exclude such evidence should be denied.â€Â  Because the issue of whether the indictment failed to give him notice of what he was called upon to defend and failed to protect him against double jeopardy was not raised to or ruled upon by the trial judge, the issue is not preserved for appeal.Â  Wilder Corp. v. Wilke, 330 S.C. 71, 76, 497 S.E.2d 731, 733 (1998).Â  However, even if this issue were properly preserved, we find no error.Â  
            A person is guilty of first degree burglary â€œif the person enters a dwelling without consent and with intent to commit a crime in the dwelling, and . . . (2) the burglary is committed by a person with a prior record of two or more convictions for burglary or housebreaking.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-11-311(A) (2003). Â For purposes of this statute, â€œâ€˜[d]wellingâ€™ means its definition found in Â§ 16-11-10 and also means the living quarters of a building which is used or normally used for sleeping, living, or lodging by a person.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-11-310(2) (2003).Â  With respect to burglary, section 16-11-10 of the South Carolina Code (2003) provides that a dwelling house also includes â€œall houses, outhouses, buildings, sheds and erections which are within two hundred yards of [the dwelling house].â€Â  State v. Smalls, 336 S.C. 301, 306-07, 519 S.E.2d 793, 795 (Ct. App. 1999).
            â€œAn indictment is sufficient if the offense is stated with sufficient certainty and particularity to enable the court to know what judgment to pronounce, the defendant to know what he is called upon to answer, and if an acquittal or a conviction thereon may be pleaded as a bar to any subsequent prosecution.â€Â  State v. Owens, 293 S.C. 161, 165, 359 S.E.2d 275, 277Â  (1987). Â â€œThe true test of the sufficiency of an indictment is not whether it could be made more definite and certain, but whether it contains the necessary elements of the offense intended to be charged and sufficiently apprises the defendant of what he must be prepared to meet.â€Â  Browning v. State, 320 S.C. 366, 368, 465 S.E.2d 358, 359 (1995).Â  â€œAn indictment phrased substantially in the language of the statute which creates and defines the offense is ordinarily sufficient.â€Â  State v. Shoemaker, 276 S.C. 86, 88, 275 S.E.2d 878, 878 (1981).Â  
            The indictment in this case expressly referenced section 16-11-311 of the South Carolina Code (2003) and specifically alleged that Lussardi entered Mabryâ€™s â€œdwellingâ€ without his consent and with the intent to commit a crime therein, and that he had two prior burglary convictions.Â  We therefore find the indictment for first degree burglary was sufficient.
            II.Â  Prior Convictions
            Lussardi argues the trial court erred by allowing the State to introduce Lussardiâ€™s two prior burglary convictions because they were more prejudicial than probative.Â  We disagree.
            A person is guilty of first degree burglary â€œif the person enters a dwelling without consent and with intent to commit a crime in the dwelling, and . . . (2) the burglary is committed by a person with a prior record of two or more convictions for burglary or housebreaking.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-11-311(A) (2003).Â  â€œTo deter repeat offenders, the General Assembly chose to include two or more prior burglary and/or housebreaking convictions as an element of first degree burglary.â€Â  State v. Benton, 338 S.C. 151, 154, 526 S.E.2d 228, 230 (2000).Â  In State v. Benton, our Supreme Court ruled that section 16-11-311(A)(2) does not violate due process because it is reasonably designed to accomplish its purpose.Â  Id.Â  Furthermore, a â€œdefendant cannot require the State to stipulate to the prior conviction in lieu of informing the jury about the prior convictions.â€Â  Id. at 155, 526 S.E.2d at 230.Â  Addionally, â€œdue process does not bar the admission of prior crimes simply because there is an accompanying prejudicial effect.â€Â  Id.Â Â Â Â Â Â  
            In State v. James, 355 S.C. 25, 32, 583 S.E.2d 745, 748 (2003), the Supreme Court reaffirmed the steps it provided in Benton to avoid an improper conviction:

            To ensure a defendant is not convicted on an improper basis while allowing the State to prove the elements of first degree burglary, the trial court should limit evidence to the prior burglary and/or housebreaking convictions . . . .Â  Particular information regarding the prior crimes should not be admitted.Â  Addionally, the trial court . . . should, on request, instruct the jury on the limited purpose for which the prior crime evidence can be considered.

            Benton, 338 S.C. at 156, 526 S.E.2d 230.
            Here, the State only offered evidence of Lussardiâ€™s two prior convictions that were required to establish the statutory element of first degree burglary.Â  Also, the court limited the admissible evidence to the existence of Lussardiâ€™s prior convictions and did not allow any evidence regarding the particular circumstances of those convictions to avoid undue prejudice.Â  Furthermore, the trial judge provided a limiting charge to the jury.Â  Therefore, the probative value of admitting Lussardiâ€™s prior burglary convictions was not outweighed by their prejudicial effect.Â  Rule 403, SCRE.Â  
            III.Â  Continuous Course of Conduct
            Lussardi argues the trial court erred by sentencing Lussardi to life imprisonment without parole because his two prior burglaries were committed in a continuous course of conduct.Â  We disagree.Â  
            At trial, Lussardi claimed a life sentence was â€œcruel and unusual punishment considering the fact[s] and the number of years that elapsed between the prior convictions.â€Â  However, Lussardi never raised the â€œcontinuous course of conductâ€ issue to the trial judge.Â  â€œIt is axiomatic that an issue cannot be raised for the first time on appeal, but must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial judge to be preserved for appellate review.â€Â  Wilder Corp., 330 S.C. at 76, 497 S.E.2d at 733.Â  Therefore, because the â€œcontinuous course of conductâ€ issue was not raised to or ruled upon by the trial judge, that issue is not preserved for our review.
            AFFRIMED.
            GOOLSBY, BEATTY, and SHORT, J.J., concur. 
        
        [1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
        [2] Mabry testified that the garage is located on his property, 126 feet from his home, and is used by the family every day.
        [3] On appeal, Lussardi contends the indictment should have stated that the garage was a building within two hundred yards of Mabryâ€™s dwelling house.Â

text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Mary Lou Moseley, Appellant,
v.
Jim Oswald, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Lexington County
Kenneth G. Goode, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-530
Submitted September 1, 2005 â€“ Filed September 16, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
William E. Booth, III, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Blaney A. Coskrey, III, of Columbia; and Ralph S. Kennedy, Jr., of Batesburg-Leesville, for Respondent.
      
    
  


PER CURIAM: Â In this conversion action, Mary Lou Moseley appeals from the circuit courtâ€™s order granting Jim Oswaldâ€™s motion for summary judgment.Â  We affirm.[1]
Facts
Moseley filed this conversion action alleging that Oswald wrongfully converted personal property belonging to her.Â  Moseleyâ€™s theory as set forth in her complaint is that the person who purchased the real property thereby converted any personal property she may have had that was located there.Â  The complaint avers:

[T]he Defendant recently has taken title to a parcel of real estate known as the intersection of U.S. Highway #1 and State Highway 23.Â  The property in question previously belonged to Plaintiffâ€™s son.Â  Plaintiffâ€™s property at all times has been lawfully stored on the property and Plaintiff has only recently come to learn that the property in question belongs to the Defendant.

In his answer, Oswald denied Moseleyâ€™s allegations.Â  Before filing the answer, Oswald filed a motion to dismiss, claiming that a necessary party, Oswald Wholesale Lumber, Inc. (Oswald Wholesale), should have been named as a defendant because Oswald Wholesale was the purchaser of the real property, as opposed to Oswald individually.Â  The court denied the motion.Â  More than four years after the case was filed, Moseley filed a motion to amend her complaint to add Oswald Wholesale as a party.Â  The motion was denied.Â  Thereafter, Oswald filed a motion for summary judgment, which the circuit judge granted.
Standard of Review
Summary judgment is proper when it is clear there is no genuine issue as to any material fact and the moving party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.Â  Bowen v. Lee Process Systems Co., 342 S.C. 232, 536 S.E.2d 86 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  Summary judgment should be granted when plain, palpable, and undisputable facts exists upon which reasonable minds cannot differ.Â  Id.Â  To determine whether an issue of fact exists, the court must view the evidence and all its inferences in a light most favorable to the nonmoving party.Â  Id.
Once the party moving for summary judgment meets the initial burden of showing an absence of evidentiary support for the opponentâ€™s case, the opponent cannot simply rest on mere allegations or denials contained in the pleadings.Â  Peterson v. West American Ins. Co., 336 S.C. 89, 518 S.E.2d 608 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  Rather, the nonmoving party must come forward with specific facts showing there is a genuine issue for trial.Â  Regions Bank v. Schmauch, 354 S.C. 648, 582 S.E.2d 432 (Ct. App. 2003).
Discussion
Moseley argues the circuit court erred in granting Oswaldâ€™s motion for summary judgment.Â  We disagree.
Conversion is the illegal use, misuse, or detention of anotherâ€™s chattel to the exclusion of the ownerâ€™s rights.Â  Hite v. Thomas & Howard Co., 305 S.C. 358, 409 S.E.2d 340 (1991).Â  Conversion is defined as the unauthorized assumption and exercise of rights of ownership over goods or personal chattels belonging to another, to alteration of their condition or to exclusion of rights of the owner.Â  Mullis v. Trident Emergency Physicians, 351 S.C. 503, 570 S.E.2d 549 (Ct. App. 2002).
Moseley submitted an affidavit in opposition to the summary judgment motion.Â  In her affidavit, Moseley declared: â€œJim Oswald personally has exercised control and apparent ownership of the automobiles on several occasions.â€Â  Moseley provides no admissible facts to support this conclusory statement.Â  The court must consider facts, not conclusory statements in affidavits.Â  Ultimate or conclusory facts and conclusions of law, as well as statements made on information and belief, cannot be utilized on a summary judgment motion.Â  Dawkins v. Fields, 354 S.C. 58, 580 S.E.2d 433 (2003); see also Shupe v. Settle, 315 S.C. 510, 445 S.E.2d 651 (Ct. App. 1994) (finding conclusory statement in affidavit insufficient to resist summary judgment).
Further, Moseley states: â€œI dealt with Mr. Oswald and had my son Dennis talk to Mr. Oswald about getting the cars and other property off of the property. . . . My son Dennis also talked to Mr. Oswald about getting the automobiles.â€Â  There is no indication of what Dennis said, what Oswald said in response, or how that conversation supports a claim of conversion against Oswald individually.Â  Moreover, that conversation, as described by Moseley, is hearsay.
Moseleyâ€™s allegation that Oswald purchased real property, thereby converting her personal property, is without support.Â  There is no genuine issue as to any material fact for trial.Â  Thus, the judge did not err in granting summary judgment to Oswald.
Accordingly, the order of the circuit judge granting summary judgment to Oswald is
AFFIRMED.
 ANDERSON, HUFF and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Eula M. Nicholson, Respondent,
v.
Betty Gresham, John Doe, Mary Roe, and Richard Roe, fictitious names used to designate all other persons unknown claiming any right, title, estate, interest in or lien upon the real estate described in the Complaint herein, Defendants,/Of whom Betty Gresham is,
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Berkeley County
Â Robert E. Watson, Master-In-Equity

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-531
Heard September 14, 2005 â€“ Filed September 20, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Joseph Todd Manley, of Moncks Corner; for Appellant.
George B. Bishop, of Moncks Corner; for Respondent.
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:Â  Eula Nicholson (Nicholson) initiated this action to quiet title to property she claimed she purchased from the appellant, Betty Gresham (Gresham).Â  We affirm the Master-In-Equityâ€™s ruling that Nicholson is the owner of the disputed property.Â  
FACTS
Nicholson and Gresham met in the early 1990s, and became close friends up until the events giving rise to this case.Â  Gresham owned an acre of property which included a boat landing, a bait and tackle shop, several mobile home trailers, and Greshamâ€™s residence.Â  Around March of 1999, Nicholson and Gresham entered into an agreement whereby Nicholson occupied and had exclusive use of a portion of the disputed property.Â  Because the parties were close friends, they did not involve an attorney in the transaction.Â  Nicholson paid Gresham $10,000 in March 1999, and paid an additional $40,000 in monthly installments over the course of the next four years.Â  Nicholson claims this transaction was a sale; Gresham, however, contends the arrangement was a four-year leaseâ€”not a sale.Â  Nicholson presented a document, signed by both her and Gresham, which simply states:

This is to verify that I Eula M, [sic] Nicholson will pay the amount of 10,000 as a down payment with the balance of 40,000 to be paid in full at the end 4 yr.

Two surveys were performed to divide the property.Â  The first survey was conducted in 1999.Â  Nicholson testified that after the first survey, the surveyor prepared a deed which was signed by both parties and notarized.Â  Gresham denies signing this deed.Â  However, the deed was recorded in January 2003.Â  Additionally, Nicholson entered into evidence a writing which accounted for the payments she made to Gresham.Â  Gresham admitted that every month when Nicholson would make her $1,200 payment, Gresham would initial on this document, indicating the payment had been received.Â  
The portion of the property that Nicholson possessed included two mobile home trailers.Â  Nicholson testified that these trailers were in poor condition and that she renovated the trailers so she could rent them.Â  Furthermore, she brought two additional trailers onto the property.Â  In all, three trailers were designated for rent, and the fourth Nicholson kept for herself, although it was not her primary residence.Â  Witnesses gave varying opinions on how much rental income could be derived from the property with estimates ranging from $275 to $400 per trailer per month.Â  
In August of 2002, after Nicholson had paid the $50,000, Gresham had a second survey performed.Â  Gresham had a fence, which transected the property, moved approximately five feet to enlarge her portion of the land.Â  Subsequently, Gresham moved the fence a second time, this time taking a substantial portion of the space that Nicholson occupied.Â  Eventually, Nicholson filed suit to quiet title.Â  
The master found the recorded deed was void due to form because the consideration stated on the deed was incorrect and it was doubtful that the parties signed the deed simultaneously or in each otherâ€™s presence.Â  The master nonetheless found that Gresham had sold the property to Nicholson.Â  He ruled that the Statute of Frauds was not applicable because of full or part performance and because Nicholson made improvements to the property.Â  Therefore, he granted Nicholson exclusive quiet possession and title to the portion of the property she claimed.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
This case presents issues of both law and equity.Â  Where legal and equitable actions are maintained in one suit, each retains its own identity as legal or equitable for purposes of the applicable standard of review.Â 
Kuznik v. Bees Ferry Assocs.Â¸ 342 S.C. 579, 538 S.E.2d 15 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  In an action at law, this Court will not disturb the findings of fact unless they are wholly unsupported by the evidence.Â  Kemp v. Rawlings, 358 S.C. 28, 594 S.E.2d 845 (2004).Â  However, where questions of equity are involved, we may take our own view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  Williams v. Wilson, 349 S.C. 336, 563 S.E.2d 320 (2002).Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
Gresham contends that Nicholsonâ€™s action must fail because it is barred by the Statute of Frauds, S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 32-3-10(4) (1991).Â  We disagree.
The first question is whether a parol contract to sell the property existed between Gresham and Nicholson.Â  See Aust v. Beard, 230 S.C. 515, 96 S.E.2d 558 (1957).Â  The master found â€œby clear and convincing evidence, the Defendantâ€™s intentions and desire was to sell a portion of her propertyâ€ to Nicholson.Â  Although Gresham forcefully denies that she sold the property, there is ample evidence to support the masterâ€™s finding.Â  For instance, Sandra Gresham, who is of no relation to the appellant, testified that appellant Gresham previously had tried to sell her the property for $50,000.Â  The master found Sandraâ€™s testimony credible and found â€œno reason to believe that she was biased or prejudicial for one side or the other.â€Â  Furthermore, Nicholson provided a payment schedule which accounts for all of the monthly $1,200 payments she made to Gresham.Â  Gresham initialed by each payment.Â  Nicholson, who paid Gresham in cash, by check, or by combination of the two, entered into evidence one check which read â€œMortgageâ€ in the memo line.Â  After reviewing all of the evidence, we defer to the masterâ€™s conclusion that the parties intended the arrangement to be the sale of property and not a lease.Â  
Next, because this case is an action to charge Gresham on a contract for the sale of land, it must either meet the requirements of the Statute of Frauds, S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 32-3-10, or else fall under an exception to the Statute of Frauds.Â  Section 32-3-10 provides that 

No action shall be brought whereby:
. . . .
(4)Â  To charge any person upon any contract or sale of lands. . .
Unless the agreement upon which such action shall be brought or some memorandum or note thereof shall be in writing and signed by the party to be charged therewith or some person thereunto by him lawfully authorized.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 32-3-10 (1991).Â  Gresham correctly states the general proposition that the Statute of Frauds requires a written memorandum, signed by the party to be charged, which contains all the essential elements of the contract for the sale of land. Â See McCathern v. Oâ€™Donnell & Co., 181 S.C. 76, 186 S.E. 659 (1936).Â  However, exceptions to the Statute of Frauds exist.Â  â€œAn oral contract within the Statute of Frauds may be taken out by performance where one party does some act essential to performance of the agreement resulting in loss to himself and benefit to the other.â€Â  Graham v. Prince, 293 S.C. 77, 81, 358 S.E.2d 714, 717 (Ct. App. 1987).Â  Where the parties fully perform the contract, the Statute of Frauds no longer applies.Â  See DeWitt v. Kelly, 256 S.C. 224, 182 S.E.2d 65 (1971).Â  Further, the Statute may not apply where there has been partial performance.Â 
Settlemeyer v. McCluney, 359 S.C. 317, 596 S.E.2d 514 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  Factors such as possession of the land, payments made, and improvements undertaken are considered in determining the sufficiency of partial performance.Â  Stackhouse v. Cook, 271 S.C. 518, 248 S.E.2d 482 (1978).Â  
The master found there had been full or partial performance and that Nicholson had made substantial improvements to the property.Â  Because we adopt the masterâ€™s conclusion that the parties entered into a contract for the sale of the land, we find the contract was fully performed.Â  Gresham conceded that she received the $50,000.Â  Therefore, we affirm the masterâ€™s finding that the sale was taken out of the Statute of Frauds by full or partial performance.Â  Further, we hold the master properly ordered the issuance of a master deed to specifically enforce the partiesâ€™ contract.Â  
 AFFIRMED.
 ANDERSON, HUFF, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.Â

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-532
Submitted September 1, 2005 â€“ Filed September 20, 2005Â Â 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Eleanor Duffy Cleary, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster; Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh; Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott; Sr. Assistant Attorney General Harold M. Coombs, Jr., Office of the Attorney General, of Columbia; and Solicitor Edgar Lewis Clements, III, of Florence, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Pursuant to a negotiated plea, Hutchinson pled guilty to grand larceny exceeding $5,000, two counts of first-degree burglary, and one count of second-degree burglary.Â  He received a total of fifteen years imprisonment.Â  
Hutchinson filed a timely notice of appeal.Â  His counsel filed a brief pursuant to Anders v. California, 386 U.S. 738 (1967).Â  In his pro se Anders response, Hutchinson raised the issue of whether the trial court had jurisdiction to accept his guilty plea where the first-degree burglary indictment was amended to include an additional aggravating factor.Â  On December 6, 2004, this court ordered re-briefing on the subject matter jurisdiction issue raised in Hutchinsonâ€™s pro se Anders response.Â  This issue is now our sole appellate consideration.Â  
We affirm pursuant to Rule 220(b)(1), SCACR, and the following authorities:Â  State v. Gentry, 363 S.C. 93, 103, 910 S.E.2d 494, 500 (2005) (holding that issues concerning the sufficiency of an indictment are not issues of subject matter jurisdiction); State v. Rogers, 361 S.C. 178, 183, 603 S.E.2d 910, 912-13 (Ct. App. 2004) (holding that an issue must be raised to and ruled upon by the trial judge in order to be preserved for appellate review); State v. Thompson, 341 S.C. 524, 526, 534 S.E.2d 708, 710 (Ct. App. 2000) (â€œA guilty plea generally acts as a waiver of all non-jurisdictional defects and defenses.â€).

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        Georgia Christine F. Howard and the Estate of Leland B. Finklea, Appellants,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Derrell Lawayne Cox, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Florence County
Â B. Hicks Harwell, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-533
Heard September 13, 2005 â€“ Filed September 29, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        J. Rene Josey, of Florence, for Appellants. 
        John Murdock Prosser, Jr., of Johnsonville and Mark W. Buyck, Jr., of Florence, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Georgia Christine F. Howard and the Estate of Leland Finklea appeal the grant of summary judgment to Derrell Lawayne Cox on their claims for rescission and unjust enrichment.Â  We affirm. 
FACTS

In 2000, Leland Finklea and his daughter, Georgia Howard, contracted to sell two parcels of unimproved farmland in Florence County to Derrell Cox for $100,000.Â  Finklea and Howard later agreed to lower the price to $90,000 when Coxâ€™s contingency financing was jeopardized by a lower appraisal. The sale took place on September 11, 2000.Â  
Finklea died on June 8, 2001.Â  In May 2002, Cox secured an administrative transfer of tobacco allotments assigned to the two parcels.Â  Howard learned of the transfer in August or September 2002.Â  Howard and her husband attempted to buy the allotments back from Cox; however, Cox did not agree to the sale. 
Howard and the Estate of Leland Finklea (hereafter collectively referred to as â€œHowardâ€) filed this action against Cox alleging the following causes of action:Â  (1) breach of contract; (2) specific performance; and (3) unjust enrichment.Â  Howard later amended her action to include an additional claim for rescission based on a mistake â€œas to the facts and terms upon which the contract was based.â€Â  Cox moved for summary judgment, arguing the statute of frauds barred any contractual claim against him and asserting no genuine issue of material fact was in dispute.Â  At a hearing on Coxâ€™s motion for summary judgment, Howard abandoned the breach of contract cause of action and proceeded solely on the theories of unjust enrichment and rescission. Â 
The trial court granted summary judgment to Cox on Howardâ€™s equitable causes of action.Â  This appeal followed. 
LAW/ANALYSIS
Howard argues the trial court placed undue emphasis on the established principle that tobacco allotments run with the land.[1] Â She further challenges the trial courtâ€™s holding that she was â€œnot entitled to judicial relief on the grounds of mistake from the terms of a poorly prepared agreement of [her] own making,â€ contending the rule that tobacco allotments run with the land does not preclude her from recovering on the equitable theories of mistake of fact or unjust enrichment.Â  We reject these arguments.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  As to mistake of fact, whether unilateral or mutual, recovery requires a showing that the mistake was not due to the complainantâ€™s negligence.[2]Â  Here, Howard conceded in her brief that either party could have discovered that the allotments were assigned to the tracts in question.Â  If Howard or Finklea had made appropriate inquiries before agreeing to sell the property, the mistake that led to Coxâ€™s acquisition of the tobacco allotments could have been avoided.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  As to Howardâ€™s action for unjust enrichment, the trial court concluded that even if Howard and Finklea were totally unaware of the principle that agricultural allotments run with the land, Cox was under no legal or ethical duty to educate or inform them of this principle.Â  As an additional basis for dismissing this cause of action, the trial court held that Cox had paid a reasonable amount for the property including the allotments.Â  
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  We find no reversible error concerning the trial courtâ€™s second determination.Â  In this case, Howard needed to show not only that Cox received a benefit at her expense but also that it would have been unconscionable for him to retain it.[3]Â  Logically, such a showing in the present case would include substantive evidence about the value of the allotments.[4]Â  Here, Howard presented no evidence suggesting that the price she received for the property was unconscionably low in view of the fact that the tobacco allotments transferred with it.Â  Without such evidence, we cannot fault the trial court for refusing to allow Howard to proceed on her action for unjust enrichment.Â  
AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY, BEATTY, and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  See Lee v. Berry, 219 S.C. 346, 351, 65 S.E.2d 257, 259 (1951) (â€œIt is explicit that the acreage allotment is made to the farm and not the person who owns or operates the farm and therefore runs with the land.â€); Jenkins v. Brown, 340 S.C. 557, 561-62, 532 S.E.2d 302, 304 (Ct. App. 2000) (â€œThe acreage allotment is made to the farm and not the person who owns or operates the farm and therefore runs with the land.â€).Â  
[2]Â  See Blassingame v. Greenville County, 150 S.C. 167, 207-08, 147 S.E. 848, 862 (1929) (stating that in the absence of fraud, concealment, or misrepresentation, â€œ[a] party fully competent to protect himself . . . has no right to call upon Courts of justice to protect him against the consequences of his own carelessness, and to disturb the peace of society by his clamors for justice which he has voluntarily or negligently surrenderedâ€) (quoting Murrell v. Murrell, 21 S.C. Eq. 72, 82 (2 Strob. Eq. 148, 154) (1848)); Turner v. Washington Realty Co., 128 S.C. 271, 276, 122 S.E. 768, 769 (1924) (noting relief will be not granted for an alleged mistake that â€œis wholly caused by the want of that care and diligence in the transaction which should be used by every person of reasonable prudence, and the absence of which would be a violation of legal dutyâ€) (citations omitted).
[3]Â  See 66 Am. Jur. 2d Restitution and Implied Contracts Â§ 180, at 755 (2001) (â€œTo entitle one to restitution, a plaintiff must generally prove that there was an unjust enrichment and that the person sought to be charged had wrongfully secured a benefit or had passively received one which it would be unconscionable for him or her to retain.â€).
[4]Â  Cf. Atkinson v. Belser, 273 S.C. 296, 300, 255 S.E.2d 852, 856 (1979) (â€œInadequate consideration is not a ground for rescission of a deed unless it is â€˜so palpably disproportioned to the real and market value of the property as to constitute an unconscionable contract.â€™â€) (quoting Holly Hill Lumber Co. v. McCoy, 201 S.C. 427, 445, 23 S.E.2d 372, 380 (1942)); Hemingway v. Small, 284 S.C. 42, 46, 324 S.E.2d 335, 338 (Ct. App. 1984) (noting â€œevidence regarding valuation is crucial to invalidate a deedâ€).
